content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This exercise is creative, and the difficulty level is well scaled, which sets it apart from the conventional exercises we often encounter.
I enjoy exercises that involve the use of modulo!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: A bit difficult at first look, but when you think about it, it's not so complicated.
I think the reverse will be a little to difficult to do in 5 minutes, but doable in the clash time

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It is a nice, creative contribution, and it is challenging but doable within the clash time. Reverse also seems to work well.

I would hate to do this one in fastest - but that is part of the deal. In my opinion shortest mode can be done as well.

Goal section
* The meaning of "π/2" is not clear. Suggest to replace it with another description.

Input section
* Please change "Line" to "Line 1".

* Please add "Two space-separated integers representing the" in front of "two angles".

Cases
* Test 4 and Validator 4 do not seem to make sense. An angle made on the clock should not be greater than 360°.

* It does not make sense for both Test 2 and Validator 2 to have the same output. In fact, the angles should be 68 (not 70 nor 85) and 90. Similar argument applies to Test 3 and Validator 3. Would you please rewrite *all* the cases and use accurate angles as input? (The only acceptable rounding should be to the nearest degree, and nothing further than that.)

Thanks.

Thank you for your feedback. 

I updated the contribution.

Thank you for your feedback.

Shortest mode has been added.

Thank you for making the changes. Below are my comments based on the revised version:

Goal section
* Suggest to change "time clock" to "analog clock".

* Please delete the quotation marks.

* Please add a note "For time before 1 AM, output {{12}} instead of {{00}} as the hour."

Output section
* Please add "or {{IMPOSSIBLE}}".

Cases
* Please swap Test 2 and Validator 1 so that ":00" is covered by a validator.

* Please swap Test 3 and Validator 5 so that "12:" is covered by a validator.

Thanks again.
